section.title: Equivalent Accumulation Rates
section.p: We would like to pause and consider a more comprehensive way to think about converting between various discount and interest rates. There are two limitations we have to work with. As we noted in , nominal rates are useless for calculations. So the first limitation is that we cannot perform rate conversions using nominal rates. Secondly, our conversion formulas between discount and interest will return a rate with the same period as the original rate. If we convert an effective monthly discount rate to an interest rate, the result will be an effective monthly interest rate. What this means is that in conversions, we first need an effective rate, then we convert, then we adjust to get the rate we need.

statement.p: Convert as indicated. Assume \iota is an effective annual interest rate and d is an effective annual discount rate.
In the following problems, first identify what rate you are given. Then identify what rate you need. Then solve the problem.

task.p: Katy Perry deposits X into an account at the end of each month for three months. Immediately following the last deposit, the balance was 225,000. The account carries \iota^{(2)} = 6\%. Find X.
Suppose the amount in a fund one and a half years from today is 100. Find the present value of the fund if the nominal rate of discount is 5% convertible quarterly.
If the effective annual interest rate is \iota = 0.08, find \iota^{(6)}+d^{(4)}.

statement.p: So far in , we have met two new ways to accumulate interest. The first is simple interest, the second is discount. Given a simple interest rate, there are no equivalent compound interest rates. However, given a discount rate, there are equivalent interest rates. Why is this?
